text: all right thank you everyone for coming out to our session here making it big without
breaking the bank i'll be joined by uh greg scallon from who's chief architect
at flipboard as well as jim from uh yelp where he's the engineering manager for
their data mining and big data efforts so making it big without breaking the bank
uh when you're in a startup everything is scarce and so what we hope to talk about over the course of the coming 50
minutes is to provide some perspective both at a high level around observations of how to effectively spend
your time and money towards building something great as well as more tactical observations
and best practices from from jim and greg on how to make the most of your aws
spend and to really scale the spend effectively as your business itself is scaling so that is what we'll be
covering over the course of the next 50 minutes and just to give you a little bit more of a
road map of how we plan to go through it uh i'll start off and offer a perspective
one person's perspective from the venture industry around observations of
um and trends around how we've seen startups spent venture-backed startups spend money and time in ways that
are really feel like effective best practices and ways that may fall short of that bar and then talk a little bit
about optimizing your costs as you grow and in particular some of the trade-offs between agility and time to market
versus cost optimizations when does it start to make sense to really start to tune the levers around cost
versus willing to accommodate a little bit more uh lower utilization in order to get to market effectively and get
your product out there and then lastly we're gonna dig in a little bit more with big data use cases
and specifically on amazon's managed mapreduce product elastic map produce around how to use ri's and spot
instances effectively to uh to drive down costs so that is the roadmap and i'll be
starting us off um with a venture perspective so and to do that i'll give a little bit more of an introduction for my firm and
for myself so i'm with kleiner perkins caulfield buyer we're a venture capital firm based out
of silicon valley uh we just hit our 40th anniversary this past year
so one of the early venture firms on on sandhill road and over the course of that time frame made on the order of 600 investments 190
ipos and hundreds of mna events uh companies including google amazon and more recently twitter square spotify and
flipboard so that is kleiner perkins i joined just this past november as one of our
investment partners there and prior to that was at amazon web services actually as one of the
running the product management team for databases so have a little bit of a unique perspective there both um for
more having worn the aws hats as well as now being in in the venture industry and i think what uh has been interesting for
me and a privilege over the past year is you get to meet and work with a lot of
many many high quality startups and part of that enables building some observations and trends
around how they're spending money and time against their goals and on infrastructure and you see some
practices that seem to make a lot of sense at least to me as a focus group of one and some that maybe make less sense
and so i'm going to look at that through lenses of stage so starting out starting
out your company building your initial application see if you have something people want then let's say you do how to
grow experiences as companies are growing and then those that are startups that have
reached scale and obviously that's a loose term there as well as talking
about some of the questions that you might expect from your board or your advisors or that you might want to ask
yourself as you're going through that group phase around whether you're spending your time and money in effective ways
so uh you're all here at this conference so i don't want to preach to the converted
i think many of you have come to the conclusion that it makes a lot of sense to start your application or your business on amazon web services
but i did want to re-hit the high points on that particularly from the perspective of uh being a startup in a
startup nothing is more critical than focus and really focusing in on your application what makes you unique what
your users really care about uh what you know you're going up against competition and and a large number of challenges so
you really need to hone in on what can you be the best in the world at and focus all of your resources at that and
aws enables that to a great degree big part of that is around the speed and the flexibility so in 2012 relative to doing
a venture vac startup maybe even a decade ago there's a lot less technical risk when you when you know what you
want to build um it's a lot easier to build that a lot more tools of advance the engineering know-how is advanced but
but the market risk is often the biggest element that you want to take out you can build it but then are people going
to want what you built do the dogs eat the dog food and so a lot of that is getting out there quickly listening to
customers iterating responding to the feedback you're getting to to get to something that customers ultimately want
and are excited about and what's so important about aws in the cloud there is it enables you to to rapidly iterate
and get out ideas and then to have the flexibility to scale those applications if they're a hit and uh it makes a lot
easier things that would have been a huge headache or wouldn't have been possible a decade ago particularly around say being fault tolerant being
located in multiple geographies where your users are handling different failure events so all that stuff getting
gotten a lot easier with aws and it makes a lot of sense to start your application there
but but in the description for this event we talk about spending your time you're spending your um your money
effectively and the interesting thing is if you look at a venture-backed startup the majority of the capital isn't going
into the infrastructure the majority of capital is going to the salaries the people that work there and the majority of those salaries are going
to the engineers that are building the product and so really the the this precious resource the scarce resource is
developer time and uh you know that's kind of a truism that everyone can say but i think the
real thing that we observe is are people being ruthlessly objective around what are the best uses of developer time and
um and making a long-term optimization on that so you know there might be there's the initial cut which is hey
should i be building all my own infrastructure or should i be running on aws and taking advantage of them doing all that undifferentiated heavy lifting
that's gotten a little bit more obvious in 2012 that it's nice to offload that to amazon where that's their core
competency versus and you focus on your application development but some of some of the stuff gets a little bit less
obvious from there it starts to get into tools and technology choices beyond just the
platform so one of the ones i think is interesting is looking at some of the managed higher level services in aws for
instance a lot of people are running on most people running on ec2 on s3 and comparatively to that few are using
some of the higher level services um let's say a dynamodb or an rds a lot of people are using those services
but it's still early days and i would say that it's interesting in talking to developers and startups about that you
often hear well i'm afraid of i'm afraid of lock-in uh i'm i'm afraid of lock-in i'd rather you know manage myself with
open source databases on on on ec2 and this is just picking one particular example and i think that's an area where
um it's worth thinking through because one i think the lock-in is lower than people it is a lot lower than people
expect it's pretty easy to export your data out of something like dynamodb but the other thing i'd say is just remember
there's no free lunch when it comes to developer time so uh yes you might you know what cost do
you want to pay to avoid all lock-in it costs in terms of time do you want to
learn how to deploy and configure a large cassandra cluster do you want to learn how to rebalance the data across
multiple nodes when you're experiencing a traffic spike and you need to distribute that io pattern across all
the nodes or do you want to leave that to amazon where that's that's their core competency so i think
uh in all aspects of kind of the early days want to be thoughtful about how you're spending
developer time and resources and are you really doing things that move the needle forward for your application for your business for your startup and this is a
really strained analogy but uh i'm going with it anyway so this is a quote from seneca the great
uh philosopher and he says plotting oxen are much more suited to carrying heavy loads than thoroughbred horses whoever
hampers the sweetness of such born creatures with a heavy pack and uh analogies flawed i don't want to be you
know accused of comparing developers to horses but the point being that um let aws do the heavy lifting or or a cloud
provider let them do the heavy lifting and you really want to focus um what what people were the best in the world
that building applications and things for users let them focus on on that one one quote in this vein that i find
interesting uh was mike krieger the instagram co-founder had a tech talk where he said you know your users around
the world don't care that you wrote your own database and i think it's a great quote because it captures this this um
point about focusing on the customer focusing on your core innovation and and getting rid of everything else that's a
distraction around that and i think one of the things that i do observe some you know sometimes in an adventure role is
you do see a syndrome where you talk to a startup and a lot of times using whatever
technology is trending the most on hacker news and i love hacker news i love new technologies but sometimes there's a
proven tool for a job and there's a lot to be said for simplicity less moving parts and and using the tool that you
know can effectively solve the problem versus being the pioneer that gets the arrows so that is a point there
now i'll tell you a little bit about as you scale so talked a little bit about the beginnings where do i want to start how
do i want to think about spending my time and money now let's say that you've got a hit on your hands the dogs are eating the dog food or they're drinking
your champagne whatever you want to say and you're thinking about you're looking at your aws bill and you're noticing it's
growing right along with or hopefully not ahead of too far ahead of your user growth and you're thinking well this is
going to get to be a pretty big number how should i think about managing my costs on my infrastructure as i scale
and i think one of the key parts there is going to be reusing reserved instances and making sure you're really getting the lowest price on the aws
platform in terms of the pricing off options that they offer with s3 and with ec2 reserved instances in spot and i
think you'll get a great perspective on that from both footboard and yelp who heavily use reserved instances so let
them talk about that the other point is having someone that's actually thinking about the costs and i don't mean this a
part-time cfo that is looking at the line items and asking incredibly high level questions like do we need this do
we need to spend this much i mean people that are familiar with the texture of the architecture familiar with the texture of your
overall i.t deployment they can have insightful things to say around overall resource utilization and provisioning
and so flipboard has an interesting concept there called the chief miser and i'll let greg talk about that but i
think that's a key point uh next coin is do you have a model and
uh so it's funny because in in um the business that i'm in you'll see startups come in all the time and they have their
last deck at the end which is the financial projection slide and uh you know those are always really
funny to me because people have their best straight faces on and they're like you know pointing out like what it's going to look like at 2017 2018 and the
product hasn't launched yet and no one's used it it's like the only thing i can guarantee is those are gonna be completely wrong and uh you know even
when you're doing and doing annual planning at a place like amazon or large organization where you have a new model you have a new business you have a new
application uh it's really hard to guess where everything is gonna go and so when i say having a model i don't mean having
you know being a wizard around exactly where your costs are going to come in at i mean a model in terms of understanding the
relationships between the inputs and outputs in your business so when you think about your business and you think
about serving a free customer if you're a gaming company or if you're providing a developer services if you're thinking
about the the amount you're going to charge developers relative to the aws services you're consuming to provide
that service really understanding the input output relationships there and how those change at various levels of scale
what does it cost me right now to serve a free user in my game what does it cost me per user active user per month per
day per year to serve that user what assumptions does that require then for
premium or paid users to offset the infrastructure cost of serving those um those free users uh and how is that
going to change at various levels of scale there may be certain things you're provisioning now that uh look a little bit like a while
their opex look a little bit like a fixed cost um that you can advertise over more users as you scale there may
be other things that are disjoint in your cost curve where all of a sudden you reach a scale where
you're spending a lot of money for them and you want to know uh what what the impact is going to be so i would say
definitely have a model uh around that and understand the implications um for your your
architecture on aws watch your metrics so you're just going to say a little bit
about asking yourself the right questions regularly what questions you might want
to ask yourself or your board or your advisors might ask you to make sure you're thinking strategically about your infrastructure and your spend
so i think really identify the key metrics that matter for your business so
i gave the example of a a gaming company so if you have
if you're serving a bunch of active gamers every day a month year you really want to understand a key metric for you
might be what is the dollar in infrastructure spend per month per average free user what is the variance
of that from your heavily engaged users to your less engaged users what about for premium users whatever those core
metrics are for the business really important to stay on top of those and from an infrastructure perspective as
you think about your aws costs i think it's really helpful to have a simplifying metric that takes that aws
bill and relates it back to whatever is the core business metric for you so if
you're a consumer application that might be monthly active users and you want to understand what's the cost to serve a
monthly active user if you are a developer service it might be a different metric or an active developer
if you're providing a sas service to enterprises it might be a different
metric but really having some simplifying metrics that you can reduce your costs down to and track over time
can be very helpful another good question to ask yourself is
what will this scale to so i thought it was interesting in alyssa's keynote this morning talking about the various stages
of s3 one of the points she made was well here's what our architecture looked like and we knew this would scale to i
believe it was 20 billion objects and then we knew we we got three billion three billion pretty quickly and then we
needed to think about a new architecture that would take us the rest of the way what's interesting about that is they
knew in advance that they could get to about 20 billion users and they had kind of a framework in their mind around when
it started to make sense to re-architect and i think that's a good question to ask yourself with your current architecture is about what level of
users will this scale to um and then what type of changes would i need to make and then how far do i think that
will get me so just having a good handle on your your cost metrics and having a good handle on where your architecture
can take you uh going the wrong wrong way so the last point i want to make is
about startups at scale quote unquote and so i think one of the things i observe a
lot in in my role is companies will say hey we think we're reaching a scale on
aws where we're thinking it might make sense to move things uh in-house uh definitely get that from time to time
and uh i'm not going to make any you know bold headline statements around this because every
company is different you're different in terms of your stage of scale different in terms of the capabilities that you have in-house different in terms of
the stability of your workload and the workload pattern so um it far be
it for me to make a generalizable statement that applies to everyone but i have noticed when the companies will
come to me i'll often ask to take a look at the analysis they've done to that makes them think it's going to be
cheaper to to bring it in house and i have started to see some patterns around some of the systematic errors or
or biases that creep into that data into that analysis and i thought it might be helpful to share with this audience
so one of the most common mistakes i'll see when people are doing this analysis is they're not using the right rice
pricing comparables within an aws environment so adbs provides reserved instances spot instances and various
types of reserved instances as well and so you can get up to a 70 savings uh relative the on-demand prices on the
website with reserved instances and so if you're comparing the on-demand prices versus the cost of going out and buying
hardware divided by 36 months that's not a fair comparison in terms of the pricing that you're using another thing
where you'll see apples and oranges is utilization i think forester did a research study that suggested that sixty
percent of storage that people provision is utilized well in an advanced environment you're using all of the storage that you're um provisioning with
something like s3 you're running at 100 utilization you pay for what you use so are you being uh comparable there also
sometimes people will be in an early stage with their startup where they're not trying to be super efficient about how they use aws yet so they're over
provisioned but then when they do the analysis then they're looking at a do-it-myself world where i am perfectly
utilized and comparing those in terms of the tco basis so that's another area and then durability
s3 has eleven nines of durability with aws you're often running across multiple availability zones is that the same
comparable you're using your own analysis maybe it is but maybe it's not and then the i think a couple other key
points i want to hear one is that you should think about this analysis from a long-term perspective not a
short-term perspective aws has released new services and features at a remarkable rate over the past few years
and showed no signs of slowing down on that and so you have to ask yourself also you know how do i want to participate in the new services and
features that will come out because you might know you're doing the analysis at this point in time but what if you know
s3 prices dropped by 25 percent what if a new data warehousing service comes out tomorrow how should i think about those
if i'm doing it doing it myself and so i think that's the point that often gets lost in analysis and lastly just are you
let's take it back to the beginning are you really focusing on your precious resources which are your employees your engineers your developers are you
creating distractions are you creating complexity are you creating things that aren't going to benefit your users your
users don't care where your infrastructure runs they care that about new products new innovations
and and i think that's really the point here everyone is going to come to their own you know conclusions here
the aws tco calculator is very helpful and so no no religious no religious
statements around this but just be thoughtful about the analysis you do and make sure that you're fairly comparing
apples and apples as as best as you can and some people will come to different conclusions some other panelists run
both in aws and on-premise that makes sense for them but
but at least be thoughtful about the analysis you're doing all right with that i'm going to turn over to greg from flipboard who's going
to talk about some of the optimizations and real world examples from their experiences
there we go hi everyone um thank you ray uh my name is greg scallon i'm one of the
engineers over at flipboard and i wear many hats as many of us do in a startup
i do software development do a lot of architecture but one of those hats i have to wear is looking out at our aws
usage i spend a lot of time evaluating what the right components are to use within aws
for our various services as well as optimizing the efficiency of those resources and keeping the cost down as
much as possible a lot of what ray talked about are the questions honestly that we ask ourselves
all the time we asked a lot of them in the beginning but you have to keep revisiting those kinds of questions as
you're marching along because some of the assumptions or decisions you made earlier on may not
have the same answers as you thought they would as your company evolves for those who are not familiar with
flipboard it's it's our service is kind of like a web app we're basically a social magazine where
you can flip through different content that's shared with you in your social networks and so we do a lot of
taking content that you find on the web that's shared by your friends and presenting it to you in this kind of magazine like fashion so it's it's not
very different from the standard website in that sense one of the first things that you have to
do as a startup is decide am i going in the cloud or am i not going in the cloud and the only recommendation i could say
there is know your requirements what i'm going to talk about in this presentation is a specific example of
flipboard so not some of the generalities of what anyone needs to do just what did flipboard go through when we had to make a lot of these decisions
our requirements were real fluffy we were building a product that we thought people would want to use in order to browse the web better than a web browser
would do today so we didn't know what that would run on we didn't know what it would look like we didn't know what the back end services would be
the only thing we knew was we had to ship it in three to six months production quality and the user interface team was going to be changing
that stuff pretty much up to the last minute oh and we had to assume that we would be
successful so you have to design it so that you can scale up very quickly assuming you are successful
so we looked at what other people done we looked at what facebook did those guys they kind of built their own data centers they even designed 480 volt
power supplies in order to reduce their energy efficiency um other companies like
netflix have moved out of their data centers gone into the cloud in order to remove all the time they spent doing some of that
heavy lifting on infrastructure to focus on the core competency we decided to go fully into the cloud
for our service for several reasons the primary one was being able to be um very
quickly as be able being able to deploy quickly as a service when we weren't quite sure
what the future set would be and at the same time being able to scale up quickly once we knew what kind of a
product we would have we then would reevaluate what whether we want to stay in the cloud
whether it was cost efficient to do that and move on from there so my first recommendation is when
you're thinking about classes if you're going to go in the cloud and make that decision embrace the cloud architecture it's very different from building your
own data center you have massive resources at your disposal you can deploy them willy-nilly
you need to make use of that because if you don't what you're going to find is that you're hiring people and spending time doing things that you don't need to
do because it's the way you used to do things it could be anything from setting up access control lists on ip addresses
which really don't make sense in that world at the same time you should be really afraid of the cloud i've seen many cases
where we've given engineers the power to deploy these things and they decide they just want bigger boxes and then they
kind of forget about them as they go away over the weekend so you're eating up money by these things sitting around there because they
have this power right from the get-go and the tools may or may not be good enough for the way you operate um
and that kind of goes into what when you're working in the cloud we found that a lot more of the engineers become
operations people they really do need to understand what are all these items that they can pick and choose from and
infrastructure and how could they use them because they don't have to go through a pro you know through a curation process to decide okay i want
to buy this give it to me in three months and i'm stuck with this they can decide i want to try this today i didn't
like that i'm going to try something else tomorrow so we kind of have this dev ops type
scenario where every developer is kind of an operations person and they follow through all the way to release
all their products this kind of evolved the need for what we call our chief miser which is
basically the role of a person who's responsible for making sure that the resources that you are going to go live
with make sense for your service as well as using it efficiently
um just real quick just to give you an idea for the numbers that we're talking about at flipboard um
in the we launched in january of 20 we started the company in january 2010 and we launched in july six months later
over those six months our development costs and amazon was about 25 000 over
those six months that may seem like a lot or it might seem like little not quite sure but that
was uh basically two people at the beginning 20 people after six months the total cost for developing the product
before we launched once we once we launched we needed several hundred instances in order to handle
uh several hundred thousand people that came on board in those first few days um at the peak since then to been around
a little over two years we've been up to around fifteen hundred instances and right now we're hovering to be honest it's about nine hundred instances a
little under a thousand um the well when i look at well what are
our costs if you look at we care about daily active user you have to find a metric that matters for you
for your product and for us it's about who is the person who comes back every day reading these magazines and are they
getting a really good experience are they spending time in there sharing what they're doing with people they care about so we care about our cost is how
much does it cost to support those people the cost per daily active user today is seven times less than what it was when
we several months after we started out a couple of years ago at the same time we've increased our
usage quite a bit over the last nine months alone we've gone up by about 5x in terms of our uses and usage and that
continues to go up so our costs are going down as our users are going up in terms of cost per user that's because of
some of these optimizations that i'll talk about that we've done
first some general aws tips you see these all over the web they're for you probably if you're in there now you're probably employing a
bunch of these but they're important they were important for us these are the things that we did early on first thing was we if you have to go in multiple
regions either because of availability or because you need to have instances closer to your
users over in a different part of the world keep your intra-region data transfer
down to a minimum you really don't want to be transferring a lot of data back there a lot of people find issues or
that problematic when dealing with databases but it really is important to think that through before you venture down that path another big one that we
found is many of the instances we use um have 1.7 terabytes of ephemeral disks on
them yet we were using ebs volumes for no good reason and we were doing a lot of transactions on these things
and we really didn't need to have ebs backed instances there we have a very fluid
deployment strategy where you can deploy and terminate instances at any time and still be functioning okay so if you can
leverage those ephemeral disks they can really save you a lot of money by keeping everything on the local disk
another key point was expanding ebs volumes as needed we have a lot of um
when you have a lot of ebs volumes uh you don't want to deploy too much in size and then you know not use it they
do cost money uh spot instances you're probably familiar with them they're great for batch jobs use them wherever
you can jim's gonna talk more about that kind of hard to wedge them into your instances when they can't just magically
go away but there are some things there but i have seen them 10 times cheaper than on demand instance so that is
something to keep in mind if you can leverage those avoiding elastic ips i've had developers
who've built their code knowing that there's an elastic ip running a service not realizing that those go over the
public address space and you're getting dinged for all the trans data transfer going over that so we've kind of avoided
those in general and proxied everything through the private address space and hidden that and only open up elastic ips in the few
cases where you have top level domains that have to be public facing and then we never write to those internally
the last thing i'll mention is rolling upgrades everyone does them differently but they can be very costly depending on how you
implement that um netflix for instance i saw a great presentation yesterday where they talk about how they will deploy a whole pool
of machines when they want to do an upgrade in parallel to their existing pool and then they'll solely migrate
users over for a given day it's a great way to be able to make sure that you can roll
back quickly if you have any issues you can look at the data independently but you're also going to have twice as many
resources out there at the same time if you don't have a large company where you can kind of leverage that other groups
aren't using those instances and you can migrate those machines back and forth between the different groups that can be
a costly proposition so there might you might have to look at doing rolling upgrades for instance
amongst your machines instead and organizing them in groups
um so what does this chief meister do how do we optimize stuff well you sometimes
you have to make decisions where you're not going to optimize your cost you're actually going to spend more money so for instance cost versus performance or
cross-verse availability i don't want to go into too much detail here but in many cases we've made decisions where for
instance we have had to deploy more stuff going from deploying static assets out of s3 into a cdn um and also into
another cdn in order to have the performance be fast when coming from mainland china for instance because for
instance cloudfront doesn't have an edge location within there so you do have to make those decisions and they will
matter you have to go back to are your users happy and looking at the data there same thing with availability we
tend to go with rds with higher database instances because every once in a while since our developers you know we're
going really fast we're throwing a lot of queries out there we may not catch all the queries in
certain situations where they will kind of spike and add burdens to your rds instances so in our particular case
we'll go and deploy this code and it may bring the rds instance to a screeching halt so instead we deploy a
bigger one and we put thresholds at a much lower level so that if something does happen we can kind of catch it and get those
changes out there to resolve it again that's in the case where we didn't save money but we actually you know we're
spending more money um so day to day the most important thing i'll say is data look at all your data
look at what's coming in from your machines we stuff everything in something called graphite for visual we stuff all of our
logs into a hadoop cluster and run hive and reports on these things that data
kind of tells you how your services that you're building how efficient they are and how you can go about making them more efficient
one of the first things we did is we had a model of you can deploy and terminate any instance anywhere anytime
we can deploy an instance of any role within about two to ten minutes depending upon the instance type and we
do that by making sure that when you hit that deploy there's nothing we fetch over the public internet everything is pre-packaged into the ami and there's
only a little bit of code that goes on and gets configured when you deploy it there is no state in those boxes everything is stored elsewhere
that one of the benefits of that is that you can now use auto scanning very well throughout your whole project and scale
up and down your machines on demand and i highly recommend that this is a very important area to focus on and nuke
snapshots and unused resources just check those things and do it whenever you can
i'm not going to talk much about ri use but it's huge for us when you can get a certain role of
machines or set of them to have non-spiky behavior but nice steady state they evenly use their cpu and memory
resources and you know you're not changing that code too much it's a great time to look at buying you know a one or
three year investment in the machines that are going to use that rather than paying on-demand prices we do on-demand
when we tend to have spiky unknown behavior and still changing stuff but then we'll go the three-year we found
that um you know the overall savings over three years would be about 80 when you buy the the heavy-duty ones
but the break-even points only about eight or nine eight or nine months out there so that if for instance you decide
to leave the cloud after you know in nine or ten months you're you're not losing money even
though you paid that three year upfront you're not using those resources and again look at your bills it's a
really important point there finally i want to give four examples of things that we've actually done that
have reduced those costs that were some of the bigger uh reasons for this when we first deployed the service we needed
to um get out there very quickly and we made a decision that we were going to go out in a language that we felt we could
implement changes to the backend service very quickly as our user interface designers were changing the product on
us and the language we chose at the time was ruby because it was great for that there was so many free libraries out
there that you could pull in or that we could pull in to quickly get versions of the software out there it was great for
prototyping and it worked in our first version of our production service however we found it very costly there's
a number of ways that we could have gone about optimizing and sticking with that language doing other things but we decided for a variety of reasons just to
convert it over to java and try to get more efficiencies there and so just focusing on the language and how you use
it and how you make it efficient was one way that we were able to save a lot of money we reduced the number of instances
we needed by 5x on that alone on both the front end and back in systems ssl decryption we had a bank of apache
servers doing that we switched it over to an elastic load balancer saved us about 20 instances right there
from from the get-go and the elb costs were just very minor relative to
that it was very static another thing i mentioned you may not everyone may not know this but
compressing all your data in and out of s3 if you can or compressing it in and out of your service over the public

so uh so the way emr pricing works in general is you're paid you're paying by machine
hour and that hour is rounded up to the nearest hour right so if you run a
typical emr job flow like this you run a job and then you shut down that cluster and
you're done now if that job lasts just slightly over two hours you're still paying for the extra amount
of time that goes to three hours um but you're not using it right your job is done that that pool is not used anymore
and so what we've done with some software talk about in a minute is this concept of job
flow pooling so in the last slide we saw we shut down the job flow when the job
was done now instead what we're going to do is keep that job flow running and if
another job comes along and wants to use a similar sized cluster then we notice
hey this job flow is free let's let's go ahead and use it and that reduces
overall waste that you're using because you share those resources and you kind of can fit stuff in
in the idle machines that you've kind of already paid for and you can see how over time with many job flows this can
work out well one of the details down here is if you're willing to wait a little while
for new jobs you can wait you know maybe 20 or 30 minutes to see if an idle job
flow kind of shows up and then you could use that instead we mostly use that feature for production jobs because no
one's kind of waiting around for for a production job to finish and 20 or 30 minutes usually doesn't matter
that much one of the benefits of this is again in that focus on developers
is it actually typically makes the developers life easier because if there's a free job flow now
they're waiting seconds for their job to start up and work instead of minutes
five to ten minute range and it also makes people a little less nervous about trying out their jobs
on new data because if you end up using emr one of the problems that you'll run into is you're
all excited about your new job and it's like ready to go and you put it up and in the first like five minutes it
completely crashes because some unexpected uh data input has has
completely crashed your program and in a normal sense you might shut down that job flow and have to start all over so
you just bought an hour of of machine time that you didn't really use so job flow pooling helps that case as well

down if you buy an upfront promise to use that machine a certain amount so
reserved instances the value proposition there is you pay more money up front
and then you pay less money per hour and the amount of money you pay up front
is determined by this class of usage this light medium and heavy
so you can use these in order to reduce your total cost in exchange for some
extra capital expenses and one of the important things about reserved instances is they're a billing
artifact okay you're not you know picking out your favorite machine in the data center and saying i want that one
for a year and you always get that machine what happens at the end of the month is
amazon looks at your billing and says oh you actually have these many reserved instances and this is how many
you actually use so i'll apply these pricings here so it's a billing artifact and
there's some complexities we'll talk about if we have time um but but this is the general idea here
and one of the things is right using these can really depend on
